isis.stitle: AIR CONDITIONING PROTECTION AND DIAGNOSTIC SYSTEM (APAds™) DESCRIPTION, OPERATION, TROUBLESHOOTING, REMOVE, INSTALL, AND ELECTRICAL CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS MAINTENANCE MANUAL - OPERATION - AIR CONDITIONING SYSTEM CONTROLS

svcprocinfo.para: The air conditioning system controls consists of electrical switches connected in series with the compressor clutch to regulate compressor operation. The system controls accomplish the following three things:

item.para: Maintain cab temperature by controlling air and refrigerant flow.
Protects system components and related parts from damage or excessive wear.
Allows design and operating condition flexibility.

svcprocinfo.para: The electrical circuit is very basic. It begins as power from a fused protective source supplied to the fan speed switch. If all conditions are correct, the current then flows from one switch to the next, until it reaches the compressor clutch.

svcsubproc.title: High Pressure Cutout Switch Operation
svcsubproc.para: The switch is mounted between the condenser outlet and the expansion valve inlet to monitor the operating pressures on the (liquid) high pressure side of the A/C system.
The primary function of this switch is to prevent the compressor from operating under the following condition: The pressure on the high side exceeds the preset operating limits.

svcsubproc.title: Low Side - Low Pressure Cutout Switch Operation
svcsubproc.para: The switch is mounted between the compressor inlet and the expansion valve outlet to monitor the operating pressures on the (gas) low pressure side of the A/C system.

The primary function of this switch is to prevent the compressor from operating under the following condition: The pressure on the low side is below the preset limits (i.e., a loss of refrigerant, low ambient temperature or system restriction).

svcsubproc.title: Thermostatic Switch
svcsubproc.para: The thermostatic control switch is a thermal device that controls an electrical switch. A connected refrigerant-filled capillary tube is inserted in the fins and tubes of the evaporator core. The capillary tube is attached to a bellows inside the thermostat, which in turn closes a set of contacts at a predetermined temperature. When the capillary tube senses 4.4 to 6.7°C (40 to 44°F), the thermostat closes, sending current to the magnetic clutch engaging the compressor, providing low pressure/low temperature liquid refrigerant to the evaporator. When the capillary tube senses -1.1 to 1.1°C (30 to 34°F), the thermostat switch opens, disengaging the magnetic clutch so the evaporator does not freeze up and stop air flowing through it.

svcsubproc.title: A/C Switch
svcsubproc.para: The A/C switch is the evaporator thermostat. The TSTAT is wired in series with the A/C system ON/OFF switch. These switches are configured to switch to battery voltage when A/C compressor operation is desired.
